# Supplemental Data

## Supplemental Tables

### S.Table 1: CSV containing all variables used to assess weight contribution to new variable {#sec-s_table_1}
<button id="download-button2" class="btn btn-danger">
  <i class="fa fa-save"></i> Download S.Table 1B
</button>

<script>
  document.getElementById('download-button2').addEventListener('click', function() {
    const csvFilePath = './Figures/all_columns_list.csv'; // Update the path to your CSV file
    const link = document.createElement('a');
    link.href = csvFilePath;
    link.download = 'all_columns_list.csv'; // The name of the file to be downloaded
    document.body.appendChild(link);
    link.click();
    document.body.removeChild(link);
  });
</script>

## Supplemental Figures{#supplemental-figures}

![Figure S.1A: Mean household income, food insecurity, and income all contribute the most to life expectancy.](./Figures/kbest_life_exp.png)

![Figure S.1B: Different metrics of wealth or poverty impact infant mortality rate.](./Figures/kbest_inf_mor.png)

![Figure S.1C: Which state you live in, food insecurity, and income-related factors contribute the most to age-adjusted mortality rate.](./Figures/kbest_mortality.png)

![Figure S.1D: We binned our life expectancy data by quartiles (after removing outliers) to ensure balanced weights given to each class.](./Figures/life_expectancy_bins.png)

![Figure S.1E: With balanced weights, our life expectancy model did a fairly good job at predicting life expectancy and did not appear to favor one group over another.](./Figures/conf_matrix_life_exp.png)

![S.Figure S.1F: As with our life expectancy model, binning our age-adjusted mortality rates allowed our model to balance both accuracy and fairness by not favoring one group over another.](./Figures/conf_matrix_mortality.png)

![Figure S.1G: It takes about 25 components to explain 90% of the variance seen in our life expectancy model](./Figures/variance_life_exp.png)

![Figure S.1H: It takes about 20 components to explain 90% of the variance seen in our infant mortality rate model.](./Figures/variance_inf_mor.png)

![Figure S.1I: It takes about 25 components to explain 90% of the variance seen in our age-adjusted death rate model.](./Figures/variance_mortality.png)

![Figure S.1J: Our engineered overall health variable (made from just five features) represents about 31% of the variance seen in our entire dataset.](./Figures/total_eigenvalue.png)
